creditline: Gift of Mr. Herschel V. Jones
provenance:
From Dr. White of Bridewell Library (see below) on December 10, 2014, after inquiring about these two leaves via email (P.67.60 and P.21.52.12)

Your Frank P. Leslie leaf is from vol. 2, folio 33; your Herschel V. Jones leaf is also from vol. 2, folio 161. They both come from the Gutenberg Bible that was sold as individual “Noble Fragments” in 1920 or so, originally from the library of Elizabeth Augusta von Sulzbach (1721–1794), then at the Court Library of her husband Karl Theodor (1724–1799), Prince-Elector of the Palatinate, at Mannheim, Germany.  Around 1800 the seriously incomplete Bible went to the Royal Library (Hofbibliothek) at Munich, and was sold quietly as a “duplicate” to Robert Curzon (1810–1873), 14th Baron Zouche on 23 August 1832; it stayed in his family estate at Parham in Sussex until sold by Sothey’s (London) on 9 November 1920, lot 70, to Gabriel Wells, the dealer who broke it up and sold it with the “Noble Fragment” essay by Alfred Edward Newton. I’ve tracked about 400 of these “Noble Fragment” leaves…

Eric White, PhD
Curator of Special Collections
Bridwell Library
Perkins School of Theology
Southern Methodist University
title: Leaf From Gutenberg's 42-Line Bible
